author: potuz
content: I'm very surprised by the speed this field moves. The paper on Kate polynomials is only 10 years old, and this proposal is to adopt it massively in the coming years. I had guessed (incorrectly I suppose) that it takes much longer to consider such a scheme to be safe for production

author: eth2_bridge_bot
content:
**vbuterin**
We're already using BLS-12-381 so if the primitives are broken we're already screwed

author: eth2_bridge_bot
content:
**vbuterin**
If you assume that BLS-12-381 works then it's relatively easy to prove the soundness/completeness of Kate-based protocols on top

author: eth2_bridge_bot
content:
**vbuterin**
But yes, BLS itself is definitely relatively close to the bleeding edge of math

author: potuz
content: Elliptic curves cryptography has been around for a while so I suppose that's been tested, the particular curve we're using is not that old but well, I guess some invariants are enough to qualify it as safe. I think the real reason I'm etchy is that I just don't understand what does it mean to "prove soundness" of these protocols. They are probably too far away from my own field to understand that.

author: eth2_bridge_bot
content:
**vbuterin**
In the Kate case the definition of soundness is very easy: you can't make a commitment for a polynomial P "behave like" a commitment for any polynomial other than P

author: eth2_bridge_bot
content:
**vbuterin**
You can state it more formally of course but it's a hash-like one to one mapping property, plus that openings work as expected

author: eth2_bridge_bot
content:
**vbuterin**
Pairings (which Kate uses) are definitely newer than ECC in general!

author: potuz
content: I didn't read much on pairings, just your post on them, but it looked to me as if the definition is just a character of a product of two elliptic curves. So it looks to me as going from a curve to an Abelian surface, if anything should increase security.

author: eth2_bridge_bot
content:
**vbuterin**
My main nagging concern with pairings is something like "if you can do *that* with elliptic curves, what else can you do that we don't even know of?"

author: potuz
content: Perhaps I'm boycotting this channel and burying deeper in the conversation the important document you posted, but promise is the last question regarding pairings. Do you know if you can replace a product of curves in the definition of pairing by an arbitrary Abelian surface with a non degenerate character? There are many more surfaces than products and you can find arbitrarily large groups of rational points.

author: eth2_bridge_bot
content:
**vbuterin**
That I do not know; I am not an expert at this kind of abstract group theory ðŸ˜¢
